Source: NZRDA & HNZ Collective Agreement 2024-2026, Te Whatu Ora pay scales
Notes: First year after medical school graduation. Standardized pay scale under Multi-Employer Collective Agreement (MECA) across all DHBs. Includes base salary only - additional payments for on-call duties (NZ$25-35/hour), night shifts (time + 25%), weekend work (time + 50%). Annual leave: 4 weeks. CME allowance: NZ$2,000/year.

Source: Market survey data from private hospitals, Seek.co.nz
Notes: Private hospitals generally pay 7-15% more than public sector for PGY1. Southern Cross, Mercy Ascot, Bowen typically offer higher base with fewer rostered on-call requirements. Benefits vary by employer but may include private health insurance, gym membership, parking.

Source: NZRDA & HNZ Collective Agreement 2024-2026, Te Whatu Ora pay scales
Notes: Second and third year post-graduation. Progressive pay increase from PGY2 to PGY3. MECA standardized rates. On-call payments: NZ$30-40/hour. Additional allowances for rural placements (up to NZ$10,000/year). CME allowance: NZ$2,500/year. Study leave: 2 weeks/year.

Source: Market survey data from private hospitals, Trademe Jobs
Notes: Private sector offers 10-20% premium over public rates for experienced RMOs. More regular hours, fewer nights. Some positions offer profit-sharing or performance bonuses (5-10% annually). Private insurance coverage for doctor and immediate family common.

Source: ASMS MECA, Te Whatu Ora specialist training pay scales
Notes: Advanced specialty training position (typically 3-6 years depending on specialty). Wide salary range reflects progression through training years and specialty (surgical specialties typically higher). MECA standardized. On-call: NZ$50-75/hour. Additional payments for supervision/teaching medical students. CME: NZ$5,000/year. Conference attendance funded.

Source: Private hospital registrar rates, industry surveys
Notes: Private hospitals pay premium for registrars in high-demand specialties (anesthetics, radiology, general surgery). Some positions include revenue-sharing for procedural work. More predictable hours compared to public sector. Benefits package typically includes CME funding, conference attendance, private health insurance.

Source: ASMS MECA 2023-2026, Te Whatu Ora consultant pay scales; ASMS Salary Survey 2023 (average specialist salary NZD 225,454)
Notes: Fully qualified specialist with fellowship (FRACS, FRACP, etc). Salary range aligned to ASMS MECA pay scale: Min=NZD 185,380 (Step 1); Max=NZD 267,980 (top step). Average specialist salary NZD 225,454 per 2023 ASMS Salary Survey. Salary reflects years of experience (typically 5-15+ steps). Additional earnings from CME sessions, teaching medical students, on-call allowances (NZ$75-120/hour). Private practice rights in public hospitals common (50/50 revenue split with DHB). Total compensation can exceed base by 30-50% with additional sessions. Annual leave: 5-6 weeks. CME: NZ$7,500/year.

Source: Private hospital consultant contracts, salary surveys
Notes: Wide range reflects specialty demand, reputation, and practice structure. Procedural specialists (cardiology, orthopedics, ophthalmology) at upper range. Some work sessional (NZ$2,000-5,000/session) vs salaried. Revenue-sharing common (60-70% of billings). Significant additional income from private rooms/consulting. Benefits highly negotiable: car allowance, CME unlimited, conference attendance, private insurance for family, professional indemnity covered.
